title: Study Protocol for “Psilocybin as a Treatment for Anorexia Nervosa: A Pilot Study”
summary: This pilot study investigates the feasibility, brain mechanisms, and preliminary outcomes of treating anorexia nervosa with psilocybin. The study aims to assess the potential efficacy of psilocybin-assisted therapy in reducing symptoms of AN, but does not involve machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The study uses a pilot design, involving twenty female participants who will receive three oral doses of psilocybin over a 6-week period. The primary outcomes are psychopathology and readiness and motivation to engage in recovery.
research_outcomes: The results of this pilot study will shed light on the acceptability, brain mechanisms, and potential efficacy of psilocybin as an adjunct treatment for AN.

title: The effects of yoga versus stretching and resistance training exercises on psychological distress for people with mild-to-moderate Parkinson’s disease: study protocol for a randomized controlled trial
summary: This paper investigates the effects of yoga on psychological wellbeing in individuals with mild-to-moderate Parkinson’s disease. The study aims to compare the outcomes of a structured mindfulness yoga program with those of stretching and resistance training exercises, focusing on psychological wellbeing, physiological wellbeing, spiritual wellbeing, and health-related quality of life.
methodology: The study will be a single-blinded randomized controlled trial (RCT) with a permuted block randomization. Participants will be divided into experimental or control groups at a 1:1 ratio.
research_outcomes: The study aims to investigate the effect of yoga on psychological wellbeing, physiological wellbeing, spiritual wellbeing, and health-related quality of life in individuals with mild-to-moderate Parkinson’s disease. The outcomes will be compared between the experimental group (yoga) and the control group (stretching and resistance training exercises).

title: Association between categorization of emotionally-charged and neutral visual scenes and parameters of event-related potentials in carriers of COMT, HTR2A, BDNF gene polymorphisms
summary: This study investigates the association between event-related potentials and categorization of visual scenes in carriers of COMT, HTR2A, BDNF gene polymorphisms. The research focuses on understanding how genetic differences affect emotional processing and neural activity.
methodology: The study used electroencephalogram (EEG) and event-related potentials (ERPs) to record brain activity in response to visual scenes. Participants were genotyped for COMT, HTR2A, BDNF gene polymorphisms.
research_outcomes: The study found significant differences in ERPs between carriers of different genotypes, suggesting a link between genetic variations and emotional processing.

title: Influence of Turn-Taking in Musical and Spoken Activities on Empathy and Self-Esteem of Socially Vulnerable Young Teenagers
summary: This study investigates the impact of turn-taking in musical and spoken activities on empathy and self-esteem in socially vulnerable young teenagers. The research finds that shared rhythmicity, particularly at turn transitions, is essential for successful conversation and may enhance well-being.
methodology: The study used a mixed-methods approach, combining psychometric testing with musical and linguistic activities designed to enhance interactive turn-taking properties of typical conversation.
research_outcomes: The results show that the Turn-taking group increased in empathy on self-report and behavioral measures, and in the General subtest of the Culture-Free Self-Esteem Inventory. The study suggests that shared rhythmicity may be essential for successful conversation and may enhance well-being.

title: Working With the Predictable Life of Patients: The Importance of “Mentalizing Interoception” to Meaningful Change in Psychotherapy
summary: This paper explores the role of interoception and mentalizing interoception in psychotherapy, highlighting its importance for patients' emotional experience and subjective awareness. The authors argue that predictive processing can be used to understand how subjective states are inferred from sensory inputs, and how this can inform therapy.
methodology: The paper uses a theoretical approach, combining neuroscientific evidence with psychodynamic constructs to discuss the role of interoception in psychotherapy.
research_outcomes: The authors suggest that mentalizing interoception can help patients update their characteristic, dysfunctional responses to emotion and feelings; increase emotional insight; decrease cognitive distortions; and engender a more acute awareness of the present moment.

title: Sex Classification by Resting State Brain Connectivity
summary: This paper explores the use of machine learning to classify sex based on resting state brain connectivity. The authors employ a classifier trained on one sample and tested on two independent samples, achieving high accuracy in sex classification. The study highlights the potential of multivariate analyses in identifying complex patterns of differences between sexes, moving beyond traditional group studies.
methodology: Machine learning approach using whole-brain structural and functional connectivity based on pre-defined regions of interest (ROIs) or brain parcellations
research_outcomes: High accuracy in sex classification (80%), identification of specific networks showing sex differences in resting state fMRI data

title: Multimodal Communication in Aphasia: Perception and Production of Co-speech Gestures During Face-to-Face Conversation
summary: This study investigates the role of nonverbal communication in patients with post-stroke language impairment (aphasia) and how they perceive and produce co-speech gestures during face-to-face interaction. The research found that patients with aphasia may benefit from the multimodal information provided by co-speech gestures, but there is no significant ML/AI impact on the methodology.
methodology: The study used a head-mounted eye-tracking system to record samples of conversations in patients with aphasia and healthy participants. The produced co-speech gestures were coded according to a linguistic classification system.
research_outcomes: The main results are that meaning-laden gestures (e.g., iconic gestures representing object shapes) are more likely to attract visual attention than meaningless hand movements, and that patients with aphasia are more likely to fixate co-speech gestures overall than healthy participants.

title: Psychosocial Wellbeing and Its' Relationship with Attachment Patterns and Academic Achievement Motivation of Foster Care Children in Save Our Soul Enfants Ethiope, Burayu Orphanage Vocational Training and Production Center
summary: This study examines the psychosocial wellbeing of foster care children in Ethiopia, focusing on its relationship with attachment patterns and academic achievement motivation. The research uses a mixed-methods approach, collecting data from 134 foster children and six foster families. The findings suggest that most children have normal symptoms of psychosocial wellbeing, but it is related to their academic achievement motivation and anxious attachment.
methodology: The study employed a mixed research design, combining both quantitative and qualitative data collection methods.
research_outcomes: The majority of children have normal symptoms of psychosocial wellbeing, but it is related to their academic achievement motivation and anxious attachment.

title: From Social Gaze to Indirect Speech Constructions: How to Induce the Impression That Your Companion Robot Is a Conscious Creature
summary: This paper explores how social gaze can be used in companion robots to create the impression of consciousness. The authors implemented different modes of social gaze behavior in a robot and evaluated its impact on human perception, finding that it can induce a feeling of eye contact and natural personal interaction.
methodology: The authors used an iterative approach to extend the computer model of the robot to simulate realistic gaze behavior and create the impression of the robot changing its internal cognitive states.
research_outcomes: The study found that social gaze can be a key feature in creating the impression of consciousness in companion robots, and that individual differences in emotional intelligence play a role in human sensitivity to robotic gaze.

title: Neonatal brain metabolite concentrations: Associations with age, sex, and developmental outcomes
summary: This paper examines the associations between neonatal brain metabolite concentrations and developmental outcomes in healthy newborns. The study uses multi-voxel spectroscopic imaging techniques to investigate age correlates and sex differences in metabolite concentrations across the brain. The findings indicate that postmenstrual age correlated positively with NAA concentrations, while females had higher metabolite levels than males. However, ML/AI methods are not used in this paper.
methodology: The study uses multi-voxel spectroscopic imaging techniques to measure brain metabolites, including N-acetylaspartate (NAA), creatine, and choline concentrations across the brain.
research_outcomes: The study finds that postmenstrual age correlated positively with NAA concentrations, while females had higher metabolite levels than males. The findings suggest rapid development of neuronal viability, cellular energy metabolism, and cell membrane turnover during early life.

title: Evaluating Terrain Indices for Soil Moisture Mapping: A Study on DEM Resolution and User-Defined Thresholds
summary: This paper evaluates the use of terrain indices for soil moisture mapping, focusing on the impact of DEM resolution and user-defined thresholds. The authors used a combination of machine learning and traditional methods to analyze seven terrain indices at varying resolutions and thresholds, finding that Depth to Water Index (DTW) and Elevation Above Stream (EAS) performed best in their study area. However, they also highlight the challenges caused by heterogeneous soil types and the need for local knowledge when interpreting modelled results.
methodology: The authors used a combination of machine learning and traditional methods to analyze seven terrain indices at varying resolutions and thresholds.
research_outcomes: The study found that the variation in soil moisture conditions could be explained by terrain indices, with DTW and EAS being the best predictors. However, they also highlighted the challenges caused by heterogeneous soil types and the need for local knowledge when interpreting modelled results.

title: Modulation of Distinct Intrinsic Resting State Brain Networks by Acute Exercise Bouts of Differing Intensity
summary: This study investigates the effects of acute exercise bouts on resting state functional connectivity (rs-FC) in cognitive, sensorimotor, and affective networks. The authors found distinct rs-FC alterations driven by exercise intensity, with increased FC in the fronto-parietal network after low-intensity exercise and decreased FC in the sensorimotor network after high-intensity exercise.
methodology: The study used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to measure rs-FC before and after acute exercise bouts of differing intensity. Participants underwent individual fitness assessments, followed by 'low' (35% below lactate threshold) and 'high' (20% above lactate threshold) intensity exercise bouts.
research_outcomes: The study found distinct rs-FC alterations driven by exercise intensity, with increased FC in the fronto-parietal network after low-intensity exercise and decreased FC in the sensorimotor network after high-intensity exercise. These findings suggest that acute exercise bouts can transiently affect intrinsic brain activity.
sources_of_inspiration: Recent studies have reported enhanced FC of intrinsic brain networks after acute exercise bouts [5,6]. However, it remains unknown how these effects are influenced by the intensity of the exercise bout.

title: Bidirectional Associations across Time between Entitativity, Positive Affect, Generosity, and Religiousness in Adolescents Training with a Religiously Affiliated Charity Marathon Team
summary: This study examines the bidirectional associations between entitativity, positive affect, generosity, and religiousness across time among adolescents and emerging adults involved in charitable marathon training. The research focuses on how charitable sporting events can promote positive psychosocial developmental outcomes, particularly in terms of generosity and religiosity.
methodology: Cross-lagged path analysis of latent factors to study concurrent and longitudinal effects of intrinsic religiousness, positive affectivity, and entitativity on interpersonal generosity and fundraising.
research_outcomes: Results support the potential of charitable sporting events to promote positive psychosocial developmental outcomes. Participants who reported higher levels of pre-training generosity were more likely to experience positive affect during training, which predicted higher levels of post-race generosity.

title: The Interpeduncular-Ventral Hippocampus Pathway Mediates Active Stress Coping and Natural Reward
summary: This paper investigates the role of the interpeduncular-ventral hippocampus pathway in mediating active stress coping and natural reward. The study uses intersectional viral manipulation strategies to manipulate the function of this pathway in mice, revealing its specific involvement in mediating active coping under stress conditions and natural reward.
methodology: Intersectional viral manipulation strategy using cre-dependent Designer Receptors Exclusively Activated by Designer Drugs (DREADD) AAV-hM4Di and retrograde AAV-cre
research_outcomes: The IPN-vHipp pathway is specifically involved in mediating active coping under stress conditions and natural reward.

title: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, Hypermobility Type: Impact of Somatosensory Orthoses on Postural Control (A Pilot Study)
summary: This study investigates the impact of somatosensory orthoses on postural control in patients with Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, Hypermobility Type. The results show that wearing somatosensory orthoses improves postural stability, especially in eyes-closed conditions.
methodology: The study used a pilot design to assess the impact of somatosensory deficit on subjective visual vertical and postural stability in patients with hEDS. Participants underwent a SVV evaluation and a postural control evaluation on a force platform, with or without visual information.
research_outcomes: The study found that patients with hEDS showed greater postural instability than controls, but wearing somatosensory orthoses improved postural stability, especially in eyes-closed conditions.

title: Aging Agents: Cross Generational Analysis of Behavior and Need Satisfaction Among Players of Tom Clancy’s The Division 2
summary: This study examines the age and intergenerational relationships as vectors of diversity in an online multiplayer video game, Tom Clancy's The Division 2. Machine Learning algorithms were employed to analyze player behavior data, revealing significant differences in playtime, days played, and group playtime among generations.
methodology: The study combined survey data from two large-scale surveys with behavioral data extracted from the game's tracking engine. A rank-based model was used for comparing independent sample means, and multiple Machine Learning algorithms were employed to analyze player behavior data.
research_outcomes: Significant differences in playtime, days played, and group playtime among generations were found. Baby Boomers showed significantly higher playtime, days played, and group playtime compared to other generations.

title: Prefrontal PV interneurons facilitate attention and are linked to attentional dysfunction in a mouse model of absence epilepsy
summary: This paper investigates the role of prefrontal PV interneurons in attention and their link to attentional dysfunction in a mouse model of absence epilepsy. The study uses a combination of slice physiology, fiber photometry, electrocorticography (ECoG), optogenetics, and behavior to examine the relationship between PVIN activity and attentional performance.
methodology: The study used a combination of in vitro and in vivo experiments to investigate the role of prefrontal PV interneurons in attention. Slice physiology was used to record network activity using evoked local field potentials (LFPs) in coronal slices collected from Scn8a +/mice and WT littermates.
statistics: The study used statistical methods such as two-way ANOVA, paired t test, and linear regression model to analyze the data.
research_outcomes: The study found that PVIN activity was modulated at long and intermediate cue lengths during correct trials in WT mice, but not in Scn8a +/mice. The peak amplitude of dF/F was significantly reduced in Scn8a +/mice at long and intermediate cues.

title: Fictionalism of Anticipation
summary: This paper explores the concept of anticipation in various fields, including psychology, philosophy, and biology. The author argues that traditional frameworks of anticipation are limited and proposes a fictionalist approach to understanding anticipatory behavior. While machine learning and artificial intelligence are not explicitly used in this paper, the discussion on cognitive processes and anticipatory systems touches on related concepts.
methodology: The methodology involves a philosophical analysis of existing frameworks of anticipation and the introduction of a fictionalist approach to understanding anticipatory behavior.
research_outcomes: The paper highlights the limitations of traditional frameworks of anticipation and proposes a new perspective on anticipatory behavior. The author argues that a fictionalist approach can provide a more comprehensive understanding of anticipatory systems.

title: Study of detecting behavioral signatures within DeepFake videos
summary: This paper investigates the possibility of detecting DeepFakes by analyzing behavioral signatures in video. The authors propose a method to distinguish between real and fake videos based on the speaker's behavior, rather than just visual appearance.
methodology: The study compares synthetic imagery that originates from different sources, including the same person speaking a different utterance, a different person speaking the same utterance, and a different person speaking a different utterance. The authors analyze the behavioral signatures of the speakers in each case.
research_outcomes: The study shows that synthetic videos are seen as less real and less engaging than the original source video, indicating that there may be a detectable behavioral signature that can distinguish between real and fake videos.

title: Verbal and Nonverbal Mismatch Negativity in Children with Typical Development: Variables Analysis
summary: This study analyzed the influence of ear, gender, and age variables on mismatch negativity (MMN) in children with typical development. The MMN was recorded using verbal and nonverbal stimuli, providing reference values for children aged 5-11 years.
methodology: Observational, descriptive, cross-sectional, quantitative study
research_outcomes: No significant differences were noted for the ear, gender, and age variables in the MMN with both stimuli. Reference values were established for nonverbal and verbal stimuli.

title: Representational unification in cognitive science: Is embodied cognition a unifying perspective?
summary: This paper defends a novel, multidimensional account of representational unification, arguing that embodied cognition contributes to unification even if it fails to offer a grand unification of cognitive science. The authors propose an alternative framework for evaluating research programs, focusing on the importance of unification and problem-solving in scientific progress.
methodology: The authors use a mechanistic perspective to investigate the issue of how research traditions contribute to representational unification, focusing on embodied cognition in cognitive science. They argue that research traditions should be evaluated based on their ability to solve problems and unify explanatory projects.
research_outcomes: The paper proposes an alternative framework for evaluating research programs, arguing that unification and problem-solving are key aspects of scientific progress. The authors also defend a novel, multidimensional account of representational unification.

title: Assessing Suicide Risk and Emotional Distress in Chinese Social Media: A Text Mining and Machine Learning Study
summary: This study explores the use of computerized language analysis methods to assess suicide risk and emotional distress in Chinese social media users. The researchers used machine learning algorithms to analyze Weibo posts and identified language markers associated with suicide risk and emotional distress. While the results show promise, further optimization is needed for real-life applications.
methodology: The study used a Web-based survey of Weibo users to collect data on their suicide risk factors, including depression, anxiety, and stress levels. The researchers then analyzed the language features in the Weibo posts using Simplified Chinese-Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count (SC-LIWC) categories.
statistics: Logistic regression and support vector machine (SVM) models were used to analyze the data
research_outcomes: The study found that certain language markers, such as pronoun usage and word count, were associated with suicide risk and emotional distress. The machine classifiers showed promise in identifying high-risk individuals, but further optimization is needed for real-life applications.

title: The Preliminary Efficacy of a Program to Facilitate Benefit Finding for People with Mental Illness: A Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial in Japan
summary: This paper examines the preliminary efficacy of a new intervention program to facilitate benefit finding for people with mental illness. The program combines cognitive-behavioral stress management and own experiences, including what was found or realized through their lives since the onset of mental illness. However, the study did not find significant differences over time by groups, but medium to large effects in each scale or at least one subscale were observed.
methodology: The program used a workbook comprised of eight 90-min sessions with one held every week, and participants joined in a group-based intervention program. The introduction was held as 0.5 sessions, the stress management section was held as 3.5 sessions, followed by the next section as 3.0 sessions, with a wrap up as 1.0 session.
research_outcomes: The study found medium to large effects in each scale or at least one subscale (i.e., benefit finding, personal recovery, subjective well-being, and psychiatric symptoms and functional impairment). However, the study did not find significant differences over time by groups.

title: Money or smiles: Independent ERP effects of associated monetary reward and happy faces
summary: This paper investigates the neural correlates of processing facial expressions of emotion and neutral faces associated with motivational salience. The study uses event-related brain potentials (ERPs) to examine how happy facial expressions and monetary reward impact different stages of face processing.
methodology: The study used an explicit associative learning paradigm, where participants learned to categorize happy and neutral faces as either reward- or zero-outcome-related. ERPs were recorded throughout the experiment, and separately analyzed before (learning phase) and after (consolidation phase) reaching a pre-defined learning criterion.
research_outcomes: The study found that happy facial expressions boosted early processing stages, as reflected in enhanced amplitudes of the N170 and EPN. In contrast, effects of monetary reward became evident only after successful learning and in form of enlarged amplitudes of the LPC.

title: Simple Classification of the Alzheimer’s Severity in Supporting Strengthening the Diagnosis of Patients based on ROC Diagram
summary: This paper presents a simple classification method for determining the severity of Alzheimer's disease using Receiver Operating Characteristics (ROC) curves based on Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) values. The proposed method is designed to overcome limitations in developing countries where MRI machines and high-resolution images are scarce, and neurologists are limited in number.
methodology: The paper uses a ROC curve-based classification method, which involves pre-processing the image through enhancement and segmentation of hippocampus and ventricular areas using active contour and watershed methods. The CDR values are then used to classify the severity of Alzheimer's disease.
research_outcomes: The proposed method has a high level of accuracy above 90% and can be applied in developing countries with limited health facilities and human resources.
sources_of_inspiration: Mikhno [1] developed the Voxels of Interest (VOI) template to control the subject treatment of people with AD.
Platero [3]introduced the analysis of longitudinal images, hippocampal segmentation, and classification of longitudinal boundaries in the diagnosis of Alzheimer's.
